newsitem.title: USA: First Tennessee National settles student loan suit.
newsitem.headline: First Tennessee National settles student loan suit.

text.p: The U.S. Justice Department said Tuesday a First Tennessee National Corp. unit agreed to pay $2.75 million to settle allegations it deceived the Education Department to get federal insurance on defaulted student loans.
Department officials said the settlement resolved a civil lawsuit that had been filed against the unit in Knoxville, Tenn., in 1994.

The suit claimed that First Tennessee Bank submitted false claims in 1987 and 1988 to receive federally guaranteed insurance payments under a programme that made low-interest loans to students at post-secondary schools.

According to the suit, the unit submitted fabricated collection histories to collect insurance on more than $1.3 million in loans and forged documents on more than $200,000 in other loans, department officials said.
First Tennessee Bank responded that it "vigorously and unconditionally denies any wrongdoing with regard to any of its activities involving student loans."
The company admitted no liability and was not subjected to any disciplinary action, Lew Weems, president of First Tennessee Bank-Knoxville, said in a statement.
"The litigation had become so protracted and burdensome, we decided it was in the best interests of our shareholders to settle," he said.
The company's stock fell $1.125 to $48.875 on Nasdaq.
